DataElement.preferredDefinition: The response describing the location where the lung carcinoma tissue originated from the primary site.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The medical science, and specialty practice, concerned with all aspects of disease, but with special reference to the essential nature, causes, and development of abnormal conditions, as well as the structural and functional changes that result from the disease processes. Informally used to mean the result of such an examination._A piece of tissue removed from an organism for examination, analysis, or propagation.:The place where something begins or comes from in either the sense of a physical location or a metaphysical source.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Body tissue, region, surface, cavity, fluid, organ, or collection of organs.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A piece of tissue removed from an organism for examination, analysis, or propagation._The place where something begins or comes from in either the sense of a physical location or a metaphysical source._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma originating in the lung. Lung carcinomas usually arise from the epithelium that lines the bronchial tree (bronchogenic carcinomas), and are classified as small cell or non-small cell carcinomas. Non-small cell lung carcinomas are usually adenocarcinomas, squamous cell carcinomas, or large cell carcinomas. Metastatic carcinomas to the lung are also common, and can be difficult to distinguish from primary tumors._A finding indicating the development of a tumor in a patient with a history of a previously diagnosed tumor with a different histopathologic profile in another anatomic site as compared to the most recent one.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma originating in the lung. Lung carcinomas usually arise from the epithelium that lines the bronchial tree (bronchogenic carcinomas), and are classified as small cell or non-small cell carcinomas. Non-small cell lung carcinomas are usually adenocarcinomas, squamous cell carcinomas, or large cell carcinomas. Metastatic carcinomas to the lung are also common, and can be difficult to distinguish from primary tumors.

A finding indicating the development of a tumor in a patient with a history of a previously diagnosed tumor with a different histopathologic profile in another anatomic site as compared to the most recent one.

PermissibleValues.value: Mediastinal or clavicular lymph node metastases

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm in the Mediastinal Lymph Nodes Or Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm in the Supraclavicular Lymph Nodes
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The spread of a malignant neoplasm to the mediastinal lymph nodes from an adjacent or distant anatomic site._An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise._The spread of a malignant neoplasm from its original site of growth to supraclavicular lymph nodes.

Concepts.longName: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm in the Mediastinal Lymph Nodes
Concepts.definition: The spread of a malignant neoplasm to the mediastinal lymph nodes from an adjacent or distant anatomic site.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.

Concepts.longName: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm in the Supraclavicular Lymph Nodes
Concepts.definition: The spread of a malignant neoplasm from its original site of growth to supraclavicular lymph nodes.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm in the Pleura
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The spread of a malignant neoplasm to the pleura from an adjacent or distant anatomic site.

Concepts.longName: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm in the Pleura
Concepts.definition: The spread of a malignant neoplasm to the pleura from an adjacent or distant anatomic site.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma originating in the lung. Lung carcinomas usually arise from the epithelium that lines the bronchial tree (bronchogenic carcinomas), and are classified as small cell or non-small cell carcinomas. Non-small cell lung carcinomas are usually adenocarcinomas, squamous cell carcinomas, or large cell carcinomas. Metastatic carcinomas to the lung are also common, and can be difficult to distinguish from primary tumors._A tumor at the original site of origin.
